title: LETTER: Boss versus student | Letters
text:
Members of the the South African Students Congress demonstrate outside Parliament on Wednesday afternoon. Picture: TREVOR SAMSON Related articles PIC opposes Shoprite CEO’s R50m pay EDITORIAL: Learning the hard way LETTER: Loans the way to go for students LETTER: Students get repaid Protesting students ‘did not threaten Parliament’ Students storm gates of Parliament in ‘fees must fall’ protest against budget TWO separate reports in your October 21 edition show up the stark contrasts in SA.
On the front page, African National Congress secretary-general Gwede Mantashe is Quote: d as saying that "universities were also not getting as much funding from the private sector as they did in the past".
On page five, under the heading, " PIC opposes Shoprite CEO’s R50m pay ", the following CEO payments (a combination of salaries, benefits and performance bonuses) were listed: Whitey Basson (Shoprite) R50.1m; Aubrey Karp (Shoprite) R16.5m; Ian Moir (Woolworths) R49.2m (performance bonus R20.9m); and Richard Brasher (Pick n Pay) R18.7m.
I am aware that each of the payments will be structured differently, but seeing these figures in light of the desperation of university students who do not always have enough food to eat while they are trying to better their circumstances must make one think about inequality.
Sheila Barsel
Via e-mail
